section.title: KVM host configuration
section.para:
In this section we discuss what needs to be done on the host system. For the Directory Server KVM, we need:
A virtual network in which we let the Directory Server operate. We use the same network as the one in which the Spacewalk server runs, see .
Disk storage. The amount of disk storage is mostly determined by the amount of data and users one wants to store in the Directory Server. Since, for us, it is just a machine to test the function, we hardly need any disk space. So, a total of 5GB for all should suffice.
Memory for the virutal CPU. Again, since we just test the function and not the performance, we need 512MB maximum.

section.title: Storage setup
section.para:
The KVM Spacewalk server needs disk space to run on. We provide it by means of a LV (Logical Volume) created on the host. The creation is done as follows:
&hostp; pvs PV VG Fmt Attr PSize PFree /dev/sda3 vg_server lvm2 a-- 931.00g 0 /dev/sdb b lvm2 a-- 931.51g 931.51g /dev/sdc c lvm2 a-- 931.51g 931.51g /dev/sdd d lvm2 a-- 931.51g 931.51g /dev/sde e lvm2 a-- 931.51g 931.51g /dev/sdf f lvm2 a-- 931.51g 931.51g
&hostp; pvs -o +vg_extent_size /dev/sdb PV VG Fmt Attr PSize PFree Ext /dev/sdb b lvm2 a-- 931.51g 931.51g 4.00m
&hostp; lvcreate -n sw -l $((25 * 10 * 300)) b Logical volume "sw" created
The newly created LV, /dev/b/sw, can now be presented to the virtual machine creation command as block device for storage.

section.title: Memory setup
section.para:
From the information of the Spacewalk project, see fedorahosted.org/spacewalk, we know from the Spacewalk Installation Instructions, from a Prerequisites section that the minimum amount of RAM needed, is 2GB, but that 4GB is recommended. We know that on our host this requirement is no problem. We have 16GB of internal memory, which can be demonstrated with:
&hostp; cat /proc/meminfo | grep ^MemTotal MemTotal: 16435452 kB
